Department of Applied Chemistry for Environment, Graduate School of Urban Environmental Sciences, Tokyo Metropolitan University 1-1 Minami-Osawa, Hachioji Tokyo 192-0397 Japan The selective hydrogenation of CO2 to multi-carbon oxygenates remains a key challenge in heterogeneous catalysis. In this work, a series of M1–M2Ox/TiO2 catalysts (M1 = Ru, Rh, Ir, Pd, Pt; M2 = V, Cr, Mo, W) were systematically screened for low-temperature CO2 hydrogenation to ethanol, and the C2 (ethanol) selectivity was identified as a critical descriptor that serves as a proxy for the intrinsic C–C coupling capacity and preserves the performance ranking at matched CO2 conversion. Among them, the MoOx/Rh/TiO2 catalyst (Rh loading = 1.0 wt%, Mo/Rh molar ratio = 1.0), prepared by the sequential impregnation method, exhibited superior C–C coupling performance, achieving 4.5 % ethanol selectivity and 10.6 % total C2 selectivity at 180 °C and 4 MPa. Mechanistic studies based on contact time variation revealed that CO serves as a key intermediate, with longer residence times favoring C–C bond formation. Structural characterizations (TPD, DRIFTS, TEM, XRD) indicated that MoOx enhances surface basicity and modifies the electronic state of Rh, leading to the coexistence of Rh0 and Rh+ species. This bifunctional surface facilitates both CO2 activation and ethanol formation. These findings highlight the critical role of Rh–MoOx interfacial synergy in enabling selective ethanol production from CO2 under mild conditions, providing insights for the design of efficient catalysts for C2 oxygenate production. Graphical Abstract Keywords CO2 hydrogenation Ethanol Ethane Low temperatures Rhoduim Molybdenaum oxide Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In recent years, the green chemistry industry and leading research laboratories have increasingly focused on efficient CO2 capture and the sustainable production of green hydrogen from renewable energy sources [1–3]. To convert these fundamental feedstocks into value-added chemicals, thermocatalytic CO2 hydrogenation has emerged as a promising strategy, particularly for the direct synthesis of ethanol (EtOH), attracting considerable scientific and industrial interest [4–6]. Ethanol is not only a widely used renewable fuel additive, but also a versatile platform chemical for producing solvents, disinfectants, and numerous industrial intermediates, making its direct synthesis from CO2 highly desirable [7]. Nevertheless, this complex catalytic process still faces multiple challenges in meeting industrial targets. One of the primary objectives is to transition from harsh reaction conditions—such as high pressure and temperature—to milder, more energy-efficient conditions [8,9]. This requires the careful design of novel catalyst systems. More specifically, during CO2 hydrogenation, the activation of CO2 and H2—transitioning from the gas phase to the catalyst surface—must be effectively addressed to achieve high conversion efficiency and overall product yield [9]. In the case of EtOH production, catalyst design becomes even more critical. The catalyst must not only guide the reaction along the desired pathway to suppress by-product formation but also promote C–C coupling while avoiding undesired hydrocarbons or other by-products [10,11]. Additionally, it must facilitate the formation of appropriate reaction intermediates under optimized conditions to achieve high selectivity toward EtOH [12]. Generally, catalytic CO2 hydrogenation proceeds via a complex network of competing reaction pathways, among which the direct formation of ethanol can be represented by the simplified overall reaction shown in Eq. (1) [12]: (1) 2CO2 + 6H2 → CH3CH2OH + 3H2O However, achieving selective EtOH formation remains particularly challenging due to the inherent difficulty in forming C–C bonds from the thermodynamically stable CO2 molecule. In most reported mechanisms, EtOH is postulated to form via CO or methanol intermediates, requiring not only effective CO2 activation and hydrogenation but also efficient surface-mediated coupling between C1 species [13]. This process involves multiple critical steps, including the formation of alkyl (–CHx) and hydroxymethyl (–CH2OH or –CHO) surface intermediates, followed by their coupling and subsequent hydrogenation. Both dissociative and non-dissociative activation modes of CO2 and H2 must be carefully balanced, as uncontrolled dissociation often leads to over hydrogenation to methane or C1 byproducts [14]. Furthermore, the stabilization of key C2 intermediates and suppression of undesired parallel pathways, such as Fischer–Tropsch-type hydrocarbon formation or methanation, are essential for achieving high EtOH selectivity [15]. These requirements highlight the need for a bifunctional catalyst surface that can simultaneously provide sites for CO2 activation, intermediate stabilization, and C–C coupling under mild reaction conditions [9]. Various catalyst-related strategies have been reported to improve ethanol selectivity in CO2 hydrogenation, such as tuning the electronic and structural properties of active metals (e.g., alloying or particle size control) [16,17], modifying supports to introduce oxygen vacancies and acid–base sites (e.g., ZrO2, CeO2, In2O3) [18,19], and optimizing reaction conditions [16]. A promising strategy for enabling low-temperature ethanol formation involves the rational design of bifunctional catalysts that combine noble metals (e.g., Rh [20–23], Pt [24,25], Ru [26]) with transition metal oxides from groups V and VI (e.g., MoOx [27,28], WOx [29], VOx [30], CrOx [31]). These oxides can introduce surface acidity and redox activity, facilitate the activation and stabilization of oxygenated intermediates, and promote C–C bond formation, which is essential for ethanol selectivity [32,33]. Meanwhile, noble metals offer superior activity for CO2 dissociation, H2 activation, and the formation of CO and methanol-type (methoxy) intermediates [34,35]. When employed in continuous flow reactors, such bifunctional systems provide a controlled environment where gas composition, contact time, and temperature can be finely tuned to favor desired reaction pathways [36]. Recent reports suggest that the integration of metal/metal oxide interfaces under mild reaction temperatures (typically below 250 °C) can enhance ethanol selectivity, although most studies still suffer from low efficiency or limited mechanistic understanding [37,38]. Moreover, the synergistic role of the noble metal–oxide interface, especially under low-temperature conditions, remains underexplored, particularly in terms of its influence on C–C coupling and product distribution in flow systems. These observations highlight the need for further investigation into noble metal/group V or VI metal oxide hybrid catalysts, to better understand and exploit their potential in continuous CO2 hydrogenation to C2+ oxygenates under industrially relevant, energy-efficient conditions. Therefore, this work systematically investigates a series of M1–M2Ox/TiO2 catalysts (M1 = Ru, Rh, Ir, Pd, Pt; M2 = V, Cr, Mo, W) for CO2 hydrogenation under mild conditions, with a particular focus on their structural and surface properties. A combination of TPD, TPR, DRIFTS, XRD, and TEM techniques was employed to characterize the catalysts. Based on these insights, the nature of the active sites in MoOx/Rh/TiO2 prepared by the sequential impregnation method is discussed in detail. We anticipate that these findings will contribute to the rational design of bifunctional catalysts with enhanced ethanol selectivity for low-temperature CO2 hydrogenation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation TiO2 (JRC-TIO-17, Evonik) was used as the support material for the metal and metal oxide active species. Prior to impregnation, the TiO2 was calcined at 500 °C (heating rate: 10 °C min−1) for 3 h in air. For the screening stage, all catalysts were prepared via an aqueous co-impregnation method without precipitation. TiO2 was first dispersed in deionized water, followed by the addition of the appropriate amounts of metal (M1) and metal oxide (M2Ox) precursors. The noble metal precursors were: RuCl3 (Kanto Chemical, 99.9 %), RhCl3 (Wako, 95 %), PdCl2 (Kojima Chemicals, 99 %), IrCl3 (Wako, 60 % as Ir), and H2PtCl6·6 H2O (Kojima Chemicals, 38.75 % as Pt). The total loading of M1 was fixed at 3 wt%. For the metal oxide component (M2Ox), the following precursors were used: NH4VO3 (Wako, 99.0 %), (NH4)2Cr2O7 (Wako, 98.5 %), (NH4)6Mo7O24·4 H2O (Wako, 99.0 %), and (NH4)10W12O41·5 H2O (Wako, 85.0 % WO3 basis). The molar ratio of M2 to M1 was maintained at a given value. The resulting suspension was stirred at 80 °C for 2 h, followed by evaporation under air. The obtained slurry was then dried overnight in an oven at 80 °C. The dried sample was subsequently calcined in air at 500 °C (heating rate: 10 °C min−1) for 1 h to obtain the M1-M2Ox/TiO2 catalyst. After pelletization, the sample was sieved to obtain particle sizes in the range of 0.30–0.71 mm. Further details of the chemicals used can be found in Table S1. In addition, the catalyst names have been tabulated according to their compositions and preparation method for easier understanding (Table S2). The MoOx/Rh/TiO2 and Rh/MoOx/TiO2 catalysts were prepared using a sequential impregnation method. This procedure followed the same basic steps as the co-impregnation method, with the key difference being the order of precursor addition. Specifically, TiO2 was first impregnated with either the Rh or MoOx precursor, followed by drying and calcination. The second precursor (MoOx or Rh) was impregnated onto the calcined Rh/TiO2 or MoOx/TiO2 followed by drying and calcination. The final catalyst was then pelletized and sieved to obtain particles in the desired size range. 2.2 CO2 hydrogenation The catalytic performance for CO2 hydrogenation was evaluated in a fixed-bed continuous-flow reactor (Reactor material: Nippon Steel SUS316; see Figure S1). The reactor temperature was controlled using an electronic furnace coupled with a temperature controller. To ensure accurate temperature monitoring, a thermocouple was inserted into the reactor and positioned just above the catalyst bed. Prior to the reaction, the catalyst was reduced under a flow of 20 vol% of H2 diluted with N2 (50 mL min−1) at atmospheric pressure and 400 °C for 1 h. Following the reduction step, the reactor was cooled to the desired reaction temperature, after which the feed gas mixture (H2/CO2/Ar = 72/24/4) was introduced at a total pressure of 4 MPa. The reaction products were analyzed using a gas chromatographic system consisting of two serially connected Shimadzu GC-8A units (1st: Porapak™ Q, 2nd: Molecular Sieve 5 A). A water cold trap was installed between the two GCs to remove condensable components (water and alcohol) before the gas stream entered the second unit. Both GCs were equipped with thermal conductivity detectors for quantitative analysis. Detected products included CO, CO2, CH4, C2H6, CH3OH, and C2H5OH. The CO2 conversion and product selectivity were calculated using Eqs. (2) and (3), respectively. (2) CO 2 conversion % = moles of carbon in all products moles of carbon in all products plus outlet CO 2 × 100 % (3) Selectivity ( C - mol % ) = moles of carbon in specific products moles of carbon in all products × 100 % Hereafter, unless otherwise specified, the unit “%” for selectivity refers to C-mol%. For validation, CO2 conversion was also recalculated using the conventional inlet–outlet definition ((Inlet CO2 − Outlet CO2) / (Inlet CO2) × 100 %). The results obtained by the two methods were nearly identical, with the inlet–outlet values generally slightly higher than those from the carbon-balance-based definition. Moreover, the deviation between the two methods increased somewhat at higher CO2 conversions but always remained within the acceptable experimental error range (Figure S2). The reaction setup is shown in Figure S1. 2.3 Characterization techniques Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) measurements of CO2 (CO2-TPD), NH3 (NH3-TPD), and methanol (MeOH-TPD) were carried out using a BELCAT II apparatus (MicrotracBEL, Japan) to evaluate the surface properties of the catalysts. Prior to each TPD experiment, the catalyst was pretreated under H2/He or He flow. Gas adsorption was then performed by exposing the sample to a mixture of the probe molecule (CO2, NH3, or MeOH) in He (30 mL min−1) at the designated adsorption temperature for 3 h: 50 °C for CO2, 100 °C for NH3, and 40 °C for MeOH. For MeOH-TPD, a premixed CH3OH/He gas cylinder (0.504 % CH3OH in He, 0.7 MPa) was used as the feed; therefore, no liquid MeOH evaporation step was required. After adsorption, the sample was purged with He (30 mL min−1) at the same temperature for 15 min to remove physisorbed species. Desorption was subsequently conducted by heating the sample from the adsorption temperature to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1 under He flow (30 mL min−1). Desorbed gases were quantified using a quadrupole mass spectrometer (BELMass, MicrotracBEL, Japan) with absolute calibration curves. Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) measurements for CO adsorption on the catalyst were conducted using an FTIR-4700 spectrometer (JASCO Corp.) equipped with a DRIFTS cell (S.T. Japan Inc.). The catalysts were first reduced at 400 °C for 1 h under a 9.1 H2/N2 gas mixture (total flow rate: 55 mL min−1) and subsequently cooled to 40 °C under a N2 flow (50 mL min−1). CO adsorption was then performed by exposing the pretreated catalysts to 1 % CO diluted with He (50 mL min−1) at 40 °C for 30 min, and then flushed with N2 (50 mL min−1) for 30 min. Temperature-programmed reduction with hydrogen (H2-TPR) was conducted using a BELLCAT Ⅱ apparatus (MicrotracBEL, Japan) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). First, 0.2 g of the sample was cooled to −90 °C under He flow (30 mL min−1). After cooling, a reducing gas mixture of 5 H2/Ar (30 mL min−1) was introduced, and then the measurements were carried out from −90 to 700 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was conducted using a Rigaku MiniFlex 600 diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm). Diffraction patterns were recorded over a 2θ range of 10° to 80° with a step size of 0.01° at a scan rate of 10° min−1. High-Angle Annular Dark-Field Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy (HAADF-STEM) analysis was carried out using a JEOL JEM-ARM200F transmission electron microscope. Catalyst samples were prepared by dispersing the powder in ethanol, followed by ultrasonic treatment. A few drops of the suspension were deposited onto a copper grid coated with a support membrane, and the solvent was allowed to evaporate under ambient atmosphere. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst Screening for Ethanol Formation via C–C Coupling Table 1 shows the catalytic performance of various supported metal/metal oxide catalysts prepared by the co-impregnation method for CO2 hydrogenation. Among all the catalysts examined, Rh–MoOx/TiO2 stood out as the unique system capable of producing both methanol and ethanol, setting it apart from the rest. Under the applied conditions, it achieved a CO2 conversion of 11.9 %, along with a methanol selectivity of 7.1 %—the highest among all samples—and an ethanol selectivity of 0.5 %. In addition, the Rh–MoOx/TiO2 catalyst exhibited the best overall selectivity toward C2 products, reaching approximately 8 %. These results suggest that Rh–MoOx/TiO2 possesses the strongest intrinsic capability for C–C coupling among the tested formulations. The simultaneous formation of -OH products, together with a markedly lower CO selectivity (76.1 %) compared to other Rh- or Ru-based systems, indicates that the Rh–Mo interface promotes not only CO2 activation and hydrogenation, but also the key steps involved in carbon chain growth. The performance of Rh–MoOx/TiO2 can be attributed to a synergistic interaction between Rh and MoOx species. Rh is well-known for its CO and H2 activation abilities, while MoOx likely assists in CO insertion and stabilization of key reaction intermediates [39,40]. The co-impregnation method employed here may allow for intimate contact between Rh nanoparticles and MoOx domains, which is essential for enabling tandem reaction steps such as CO formation, hydrogenation, and C–C bond formation. In comparison, Pt–CrOx/TiO2 also exhibited ethanol formation (1.2 %), yet its overall CO2 conversion remained low (3.0 %), and no C2H6 was detected. The absence of other C2 products suggests that the ethanol observed may originate from isolated or incomplete C–C coupling events rather than from a robust pathway involving effective carbon–carbon bond formation. Therefore, although Pt–CrOx shows some C–C coupling activity, its contribution is quantitatively and mechanistically limited. Ru-based catalysts, such as Ru–VOx/TiO2 and Ru–CrOx/TiO2, showed the highest CO2 conversions (up to 54.4 %) but yielded CO with nearly complete selectivity (>97 %), highlighting their strong reverse water–gas shift (RWGS) tendency with minimal further hydrogenation. Similarly, other Rh-based systems (e.g., Rh–VOx, Rh–CrOx) exhibited moderate activity but no ethanol formation, reaffirming that MoOx uniquely enables productive C–C coupling in the Rh-based system. Ir-, Ni-, Pd-, and Pt-based catalysts generally showed low CO2 conversions and negligible alcohol production. While some (e.g., Ir–MoOx, Pd–MoOx) produced trace amounts of methanol, none yielded detectable ethanol, further emphasizing the exceptional behavior of the Rh–MoOx combination. The results shown in Table 1 clearly demonstrate that Rh–MoOx/TiO2 exhibits meaningful C–C coupling activity leading to ethanol formation, whereas other systems—despite high activity (Ru) or isolated ethanol detection (Pt–CrOx)—lack either sufficient conversion or consistent selectivity to be considered viable for higher oxygenate production. These findings underscore the importance of precisely tailored metal–oxide interactions in steering CO2 hydrogenation beyond the RWGS reaction toward value-added multi-carbon products. 3.2 Effect of catalyst preparation method on C–C coupling and product selectivity The method of catalyst preparation was found to influence the performance of the Rh–MoOx/TiO2 system in CO2 hydrogenation. To evaluate this effect, three preparation strategies ((i) co-impregnation of Rh and Mo precursors: Rh-MoOx/TiO2, (ii) the sequential impregnation with Mo first (Mo–impregnation, calcination, then Rh–impregnation, calcination): Rh/MoOx/TiO2, (iii) the sequential impregnation with Rh first (Rh–impregnation, calcination, then Mo–impregnation, calcination): MoOx/Rh/TiO2) were applied to synthesize catalysts with the same composition (1 wt% Rh, Mo/Rh molar ratio = 1). The catalytic performance of each sample was evaluated at 180 °C, and the results are summarized in Fig. 1(a) and (b) (raw data are provided in Figure S3). Among the three methods, the sequential method with Rh introduced first (MoOx/Rh/TiO2) demonstrated the best overall performance, achieving the highest CO2 conversion (5.3 %), ethanol selectivity (4.5 %), and total C2 product selectivity (EtOH + C2H6 = 10.6 %). This result suggests that pre-deposition of Rh prior to Mo incorporation is particularly beneficial for forming active Rh–MoOx interfacial structures that promote C–C bond formation. In contrast, the co-impregnated catalyst, though reasonably active (CO2 conversion 4.2 %), showed a lower ethanol selectivity (3.3 %) and a higher tendency toward undesired CH4 formation (37.2 %). Similarly, the Rh/MoOx/TiO2 exhibited the highest CH4 selectivity (43.6 %) and the lowest ethanol selectivity (2.8 %) among the three, indicating that post-deposition of Rh on pre-formed MoOx leads to suboptimal interaction for C–C coupling. The differences in performance may arise from the spatial distribution and electronic structure of the Rh–MoOx interface. When Rh is deposited first, followed by Mo, the resulting configuration may allow MoOx to decorate or partially cover the Rh nanoparticles, facilitating stronger electronic interactions or dual-site mechanisms at the interface [41]. This structure appears to be more favorable for ethanol formation than configurations obtained by co-deposition or reverse sequencing. These findings demonstrate that, beyond composition and reaction conditions, the preparation method plays a critical role in directing catalytic behavior, particularly in terms of C–C coupling efficiency and alcohol selectivity. Further characterization may provide insight into how metal–oxide interface morphology correlates with product distribution. Based on these results, the subsequent studies focused on MoOx/Rh/TiO2 catalysts. 3.3 Effect of Rh loading and Mo/Rh molar ratio on C–C coupling and alcohol selectivity To investigate the influence of Rh content on catalytic performance, a series of catalysts with varying Rh loadings (0.1–5 wt%) were prepared while maintaining a constant Mo/Rh molar ratio of 1. As shown in Fig. 2(a), the CO2 conversion and alcohol selectivity exhibited a strong dependence on Rh loading. At very low Rh content (0.1 wt%), the catalyst showed poor activity (CO2 conversion < 1 %) and negligible ethanol formation. Increasing the Rh loading to 0.5 wt% led to a significant improvement in performance, with CO2 conversion rising to 5.2 % and ethanol selectivity reaching 1.6 %. Both methanol and ethanol selectivity increased further at 1–2 wt% Rh, peaking at 1 wt% with methanol and ethanol selectivity of 21.2 % and 3.0 %, respectively. These results indicate that 1–2 wt% Rh provides an optimal balance between CO2 activation and C–C coupling efficiency. Beyond this range, further increasing Rh content to 3 wt% resulted in a higher CO2 conversion (11.9 %) but a sharp drop in ethanol selectivity (0.5 %) and a rise in C2H6 and CH4 formation, suggesting excessive hydrogenation. At 5 wt%, the selectivity profile shifted back toward CO and methanol, accompanied by a loss of C2 product selectivity. These trends suggest that excessive Rh may disrupt the synergy with MoOx, possibly through Rh aggregation or site saturation. A complementary set of experiments was conducted to evaluate the effect of Mo/Rh molar ratio at a fixed Rh content of 1 wt%. As shown in Fig. 2(b), the introduction of MoOx has a profound effect on both activity and selectivity. In the absence of Mo (Mo/Rh molar ratio = 0), the catalyst exhibited the highest CO2 conversion (14.3 %) but produced almost exclusively CH4 (99.2 %), highlighting a strong tendency toward over hydrogenation by Rh. Upon gradual addition of MoOx (Mo/Rh molar ratio = 0.25–1.0), CH4 selectivity declined sharply while alcohol formation improved significantly. At Mo/Rh molar ratio = 1, methanol and ethanol selectivity reached maxima of 28.5 % and 3.5 %, respectively—confirming that the cooperative interaction between Rh and MoOx is essential for suppressing over hydrogenation and promoting C–C coupling. However, further increasing the Mo/Rh molar ratio to ≥ 2 led to a decline in CO2 conversion and ethanol selectivity. At Mo/Rh molar ratio = 3, ethanol selectivity dropped to 0.6 %, suggesting that an excess of MoOx may dilute the active Rh–MoOx interface or hinder reactant accessibility. The results from both Fig. 2(a) and (b) collectively highlight the need for precise tuning of both metal loading and promoter composition. Optimal ethanol formation was observed when Rh loading was in the range of 1–2 wt% and the Mo/Rh molar ratio was close to unity. Deviation from this compositional balance—either by overloading Rh or Mo—led to decreased C–C coupling activity, reduced alcohol selectivity, or excessive formation of undesired CH4. These observations reinforce the idea that ethanol formation via CO2 hydrogenation requires more than just active metal centers; it is the dynamic interface between Rh and MoOx that enables key elementary steps, including CO2 activation, intermediate stabilization, and CHx*–CO* coupling. Fine control over Rh–MoOx synergy is therefore crucial for directing selectivity toward C2 oxygenates. 3.4 Optimization of reaction conditions for ethanol formation The effect of reaction parameters on ethanol production was investigated using the MoOx/Rh/TiO2 catalyst with a fixed composition (1 wt% Rh, Mo/Rh molar ratio = 1). Two key variables were explored: the reduction temperature of the catalyst prior to reaction and the reaction temperature during CO2 hydrogenation. As shown in Fig. 3(a), varying the H2 reduction temperature from 200 to 600 °C had only a minor effect on CO2 conversion, which remained nearly constant (∼7.3–7.6 %). However, product selectivity was significantly influenced. At lower reduction temperatures (200–300 °C), methanol was the dominant product, with ethanol either absent or present in trace amounts. Ethanol selectivity increased steadily with reduction temperature and reached a maximum of 3.5 % at 450 °C. Beyond this point, further reduction led to a gradual decline in ethanol selectivity, despite a continued increase in methanol yield. At 600 °C, methanol selectivity reached 27.3 %, while ethanol dropped to 2.2 %. CO selectivity also increased continuously with reduction temperature, from 2.6 % to 31.0 %. These trends suggest that a moderate reduction temperature (∼400/450 °C) provides the optimal balance for forming active Rh–MoOx interfacial sites that facilitate both CO hydrogenation and C–C coupling, while higher temperatures may over-reduce Mo species or cause sintering of Rh particles [42], thereby suppressing ethanol formation. The influence of reaction temperature was evaluated separately, using a fresh catalyst without prior long-term stabilization. As shown in Fig. 3(b), CO2 conversion increased steadily from 2.5 % at 160 °C to 24.8 % at 260 °C. In parallel, CO selectivity decreased sharply from 63.8 % to 8.1 %, indicating a shift from the RWGS reaction toward further hydrogenation pathways at elevated temperatures. Ethanol was first detected at 180 °C, with a maximum selectivity of 1.52 % at 200 °C, followed by a gradual decline at higher temperatures. It is important to note that the ethanol selectivity observed in the temperature screening was lower than that obtained under optimized reduction conditions. This discrepancy is attributed to the use of a fresh catalyst in this experiment. Based on previous observations, this catalyst required at least 4 h of on-stream operation to reach a stable state with enhanced C–C coupling activity. Therefore, the lower ethanol yield in this case likely reflects the transient behavior of the unstabilized catalyst and does not indicate a fundamental limitation of the system under high-temperature conditions. Taken together, these results demonstrate that both catalyst pretreatment and reaction temperature are critical for tuning product selectivity in CO2 hydrogenation. CO selectivity increases with reduction temperature but decreases with reaction temperature. Methanol selectivity increases with both reduction and reaction temperature, indicating enhanced CO hydrogenation. Ethanol selectivity exhibits a volcano-shaped dependence on reduction temperature, peaking at 400/450 °C, and a mild maximum at 200–220 °C in the reaction temperature series. Hydrocarbon byproducts such as CH4 and C2H6 remained negligible under all tested conditions, suggesting that the Rh–MoOx interface favors oxygenate formation over deep hydrogenation. Overall, a moderate reduction temperature (∼400/450 °C) and a reaction temperature range of 200–240 °C, combined with sufficient catalyst stabilization time, are necessary to maximize ethanol production in the MoOx/Rh/TiO2 system. These findings highlight the importance of balancing redox pretreatment and operational conditions to preserve and activate bifunctional metal–oxide interfaces capable of promoting C–C coupling during CO2 hydrogenation. 3.5 Kinetic analysis To elucidate the kinetic behavior and reaction mechanism of CO2 hydrogenation over the MoOx/Rh/TiO2 catalyst, a series of experiments were conducted by varying the space velocity (SV) from 24,000 to 3000 mL g−1 h−1 (corresponding to increasing contact time). The catalytic performances at different SV values are summarized in Fig. 4. (raw data are provided in Figure S4) A clear inverse relationship was observed between SV and CO2 conversion: as contact time increased (1/SV from 0.15 to 1.2 s·g·mL−1), CO2 conversion rose steadily from 3.3 % to 7.7 %, indicating that longer residence times enhance CO2 utilization. This trend reflects the expected kinetics of a heterogeneous catalytic system, where longer contact time promotes higher conversion [43]. More importantly, selectivity profiles reveal mechanistic insights. CO selectivity decreased sharply, from 40.2 % at the highest SV (shortest contact time) to 22.3 % at the lowest SV. This strongly suggests that CO, initially formed via the RWGS reaction, undergoes secondary hydrogenation at longer residence times [44]. In contrast, CH4 selectivity increased dramatically, from 33.0 % to 62.5 %, reinforcing the notion of a sequential reaction pathway (Eq. (4)): (4) CO2 → CO → CH4 The selectivity of methanol also declined with increasing contact time (from 22.9 % to 8.9 %), implying that methanol is either further hydrogenated to methane or outcompeted by the dominant RWGS–methanation sequence at longer residence times. This behavior underscores the kinetic fragility of oxygenates in strongly reducing environments. In contrast, ethanol selectivity showed a more complex trend. It increased initially from 2.4 % to 3.2 % as contact time extended from 0.15 to 0.6 s·g·mL−1, but slightly decreased to 3.0 % at the longest contact time. Similarly, ethane selectivity increased steadily from 1.5 % to 3.4 %. This dual trend suggests that moderate contact time facilitates C–C coupling, leading to ethanol formation. Excessive residence time may promote hydrogenolysis of C–C bonds or further hydrogenation of ethanol to ethane [45]. A balance must be struck between sufficient intermediate surface coverage (for C–C coupling) and avoidance of over-hydrogenation. These results support a multi-step reaction network over Rh–MoOx/TiO2: 1. CO2 → CO (RWGS) 2. CO + H2 → CH4 (via methanation) 3. CO2/CO + H2 → CH3OH 4. CHx intermediates + CO/CH3OH → EtOH (C–C coupling) 5. EtOH → C2H6 (hydrogenolysis/hydrogenation) Overall, this study confirms that C–C coupling is most effective at intermediate contact times, where CO coverage and surface hydrogen availability are well balanced. Excessive contact time favors thermodynamically downhill full hydrogenation pathways, while insufficient time restricts coupling opportunities. This kinetic behavior aligns well with earlier findings on reduction pretreatment and preparation methods, further highlighting that the Rh–MoOx interface provides an active site ensemble with distinct time-dependent reactivity, capable of directing the reaction pathway toward C2 oxygenates under optimized conditions. To summarize these mechanistic insights, a scheme of the proposed reaction pathways is provided in Figure S5. 3.6 Surface acidity, basicity, and methanol adsorption To elucidate the physicochemical origins of ethanol formation over MoOx/Rh/TiO2 catalysts, we conducted CO2-TPD, NH3-TPD, and methanol-TPD analyses on a series of representative samples with varied Rh and Mo loadings ( Fig. 5). For clarity, the catalyst compositions are denoted as MoOx(x)/Rh(y)/TiO2, where x and y represent the Mo and Rh loadings in wt%. The nominal Rh and Mo loadings, together with the corresponding Mo/Rh molar ratios, are summarized in Table S3. In the case of MoOx(0.9)/Rh(1)/TiO2, the Mo/Rh molar ratio is approximately 1.0, corresponding to 0.9 wt% Mo. CO2-TPD analysis was conducted to investigate the nature and strength of surface basic sites responsible for CO2 adsorption and activation. As shown in Fig. 5(a), MoOx(0.9)/TiO2 catalysts exhibited relatively weak desorption signals with low-temperature peaks below 200 °C, indicating predominantly weak basic sites. In contrast, the MoOx(0.9)/Rh(1)/TiO2 catalyst showed a markedly enhanced desorption peak centered at approximately 270 °C, suggesting the generation of new moderate-strength basic sites arising from the synergistic interaction between Rh and Mo species. Compared to Rh(1)/TiO2, the presence of MoOx notably increased CO2 adsorption capacity and shifted the desorption peak to higher temperatures, implying stronger CO2 binding. Meanwhile, when the Mo content was further increased to 4.7 wt% [MoOx(4.7)/Rh(1)/TiO2], the main peak slightly shifted to lower temperatures (∼250 °C) and the overall intensity decreased, possibly due to MoOx agglomeration or excessive coverage of Rh sites, thereby reducing the active interfacial area. The catalyst with both high Rh and Mo loadings [MoOx(4.7)/Rh(5)/TiO2] exhibited a broad desorption profile with multiple overlapping peaks, indicating a wider distribution of CO2 adsorption sites but lower uniformity. These results indicate that the MoOx(0.9)/Rh(1)/TiO2 catalyst achieved the optimal balance of CO2 adsorption strength and site density, which may account for its superior performance in promoting C–C coupling and ethanol formation. Enhanced CO2 binding at moderate temperatures facilitates the stabilization of key intermediates, thereby contributing to deeper hydrogenation and carbon chain propagation. NH3-TPD analysis was conducted to investigate the surface acidity of the Rh–MoOx/TiO2 catalysts, as surface acid sites play a vital role in stabilizing reaction intermediates and facilitating C–C coupling during CO2 hydrogenation [46]. As shown in Fig. 5(b), all catalysts exhibited broad NH3 desorption profiles ranging from approximately 150 to 500 °C, indicative of the coexistence of weak to medium acid sites. The reference Rh(1)/TiO2 sample displayed a desorption peak centered around 250–300 °C, which is typically attributed to Lewis acid sites associated with the TiO2 support and dispersed Rh species. With the introduction of MoOx, the acid strength and distribution changed significantly. In particular, MoOx(0.9)/TiO2 exhibited stronger desorption extending to higher temperatures, suggesting the formation of additional acid sites—likely related to surface polymolybdate species [47]. Among the bimetallic catalysts, MoOx(0.9)/Rh(1)/TiO2 exhibited the most intense and well-balanced NH₃ desorption profile across the full temperature range. This indicates a rich and optimal distribution of surface acid sites, which is considered beneficial for the stabilization of C2-type intermediates and ethanol selectivity. By contrast, increasing the Mo loading to 4.7 wt% in MoOx(4.7)/Rh(1)/TiO2 led to a broader desorption signal with slightly reduced intensity, suggesting that excessive MoOx may dilute or partially mask accessible acidic sites. Furthermore, MoOx(4.7)/Rh(5)/TiO2, which contains higher Rh content, exhibited a significant decrease in acid site density, possibly due to surface site blocking or sintering effects under high metal loading. These results highlight that a balanced Mo/Rh ratio (1.0 in this case) leads to a favorable acid environment, which may synergize with basic sites (as demonstrated in CO2-TPD) to facilitate ethanol formation under mild conditions. To further explore the interaction between methanol and catalyst surfaces, MeOH-TPD was performed to investigate the adsorption and activation characteristics of methanol. As shown in Fig. 5(c), all catalysts exhibited desorption peaks between 150 °C and 500 °C, but with markedly different intensities and profiles, indicating variations in methanol binding strength and surface site availability. Among them, MoOx(0.9)/TiO2 showed the most intense and broadest desorption profile, peaking around 250 °C, suggesting a high density of moderate-strength methanol adsorption sites—likely attributable to the surface MoO or hydroxyl species. Interestingly, the introduction of 1 wt% Rh to form MoOx(0.9)/Rh(1)/TiO2 slightly decreases the desorption intensity while maintaining a broad profile. This indicates that Rh may promote methanol activation, leading to a decrease in retained methanol, yet still preserving sufficient surface affinity for reaction intermediates. In contrast, the Rh(1)/TiO2 sample shows much weaker desorption, consistent with the lack of strong methanol-binding sites on pure Rh or TiO2 surfaces. For the MoOx(4.7)/Rh(1)/TiO2 and MoOx(4.7)/Rh(5)/TiO2 catalysts, a further decline in desorption intensity is observed, likely due to excessive MoOx coverage and high Rh loading, respectively. These conditions may reduce the number of available adsorption sites or promote rapid methanol decomposition, lowering the observed MeOH signal. MoOx(0.9)/Rh(1)/TiO2 sample achieved a favorable balance between methanol adsorption and activation, which is considered beneficial for enhancing C–C coupling toward ethanol formation. To investigate the reducibility of Rh and Mo species and their interactions with the TiO2 support, H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was conducted on the MoOx/Rh/TiO2 catalyst (Figure S6). A sharp reduction peak centered around 140 °C can be attributed to the facile reduction of Rh3+ species to metallic Rh0, suggesting a high dispersion of Rh on the TiO2 surface. A broad and weak reduction feature extending from 600 to 800 °C likely corresponds to the reduction of MoOx species strongly interacting with the support and/or stabilized via Rh–MoOx interfacial sites. The ease of Rh reduction at low temperature and the stabilization of MoOx under reductive conditions may contribute to the formation of active interfacial sites for C–C coupling reactions during CO2 hydrogenation. These findings support the notion that the MoOx(0.9)/Rh(1)/TiO2 catalyst provides an optimal balance between methanol adsorption strength and surface reactivity, enabling efficient methanol utilization and facilitating C–C coupling toward ethanol. This further corroborates the superior C2 alcohol selectivity observed in the catalytic tests. 3.7 CO-DRIFTS analysis of Rh–MoOx catalysts To gain insight into the nature of CO adsorption and the electronic/coordination environment of Rh species, CO-DRIFTS measurements were conducted after CO exposure at room temperature. As shown in Fig. 6, both catalysts display distinct spectral features in the carbonyl stretching region (2200–1800 cm−1), but with notable differences that correlate with their ethanol selectivity (raw data are provided in Figure S7). For the MoOx(0.9)/Rh(1)/TiO2 catalyst—exhibiting the highest C–C coupling activity—two characteristic bands are observed at 2094 cm−1 and 2029 cm−1, assignable to Rh+-(CO)2 symmetric and asymmetric stretching, respectively. The simultaneous appearance of these two bands suggests the presence of isolated Rh+ sites capable of forming di-carbonyl complexes, which have been reported as key intermediates favoring the coupling of CO-derived species toward C2 oxygenates such as ethanol [48,49]. In contrast, the MoOx(4.7)/Rh(5)/TiO2 catalyst—associated with poor ethanol selectivity—shows only a single band around 2057 cm−1, corresponding to linearly adsorbed CO on metallic Rh0 sites [48,49]. The absence of Rh+-(CO)2 features in this catalyst implies a lack of suitable Rh+ sites for C–C bond formation. Furthermore, the excessive Rh and Mo loading likely leads to larger Rh clusters or MoOx domains, reducing the fraction of highly dispersed Rh+ centers. To further evaluate the effect of the preparation sequence, CO-DRIFTS spectra of Rh/MoOx/TiO2 (Mo first) and MoOx/Rh/TiO2 (Rh first) are compared in Figure S8. The relative intensities and band positions of linear and bridged CO differ between the two catalysts, indicating distinct Rh–MoOx interfacial environments depending on the deposition order of Mo and Rh precursors. Taken together, these CO-DRIFTS results suggest that the coexistence of Rh+–dicarbonyl species (symmetric and asymmetric) and a moderate degree of Rh0 is essential for promoting C–C coupling, in agreement with the catalytic trends. A reference spectrum for MoOx/TiO2 (without CO adsorption) is provided in Figure S9 to confirm the absence of CO-binding capability of the support or MoOx alone. 3.8 Structural characterization To gain structural insights into the reduced catalysts, XRD and HAADF-STEM analyses were carried out. As shown in Fig. 7(a), the XRD patterns of the reduced MoOx/Rh/TiO2 and Rh/TiO2 samples display diffraction peaks corresponding exclusively to the anatase and rutile phases of TiO2. No characteristic reflections assignable to Rh or Mo species were observed, indicating that these species were highly dispersed. This observation is consistent with the low Rh and Mo loadings (1.0 wt% and 0.9 wt%, respectively) and suggests the absence of large crystalline Rh or MoOx aggregates. In addition, a side-by-side comparison of Rh/MoOx/TiO2 (Mo first, Rh second) and MoOx/Rh/TiO2 (Rh first) is provided in Figure S10. Like the other samples, no crystalline Rh- or Mo-containing phases were detected in either case. This indicates that the differences observed between the two preparation sequences are not due to bulk phase formation but rather originate from interfacial structural effects. Further morphological observation by HAADF-STEM (Fig. 7(b)) revealed the presence of bright nanoparticles homogeneously dispersed on the TiO2 surface. These particles exhibited an average diameter of approximately 1.2 nm, suggesting the formation of ultrasmall Rh-based clusters. This high dispersion likely contributes to the enhanced catalytic activity and selectivity observed in the sequentially prepared MoOx/Rh/TiO2 sample. Additional TEM data for catalysts, as well as for the samples after reaction, are provided in Figure S11. 4 Conclusion A series of supported M1-M2Ox catalysts were investigated for low-temperature CO2 hydrogenation, with particular focus on C–C bond formation. The MoOx/Rh/TiO2 catalyst (Rh loading = 1.0 wt%, Mo/Rh molar ratio = 1.0) exhibited the highest activity and C2 product selectivity, achieving 4.5 % ethanol selectivity and 10.6 % total C2 selectivity at 180 °C under optimized conditions. Mechanistic insights suggest that CO is a key intermediate and that longer contact time promotes further hydrogenation and C–C coupling. Surface characterizations revealed that MoOx enhances basicity, maintains acidity, and modifies interactions with methanol. Analysis confirmed the coexistence of Rh0 and Rh+ species, indicating a bifunctional surface that facilitates both CO2 activation and ethanol formation. These findings demonstrate that the formation of highly dispersed Rh–MoOx interfacial sites is critical for enabling ethanol production from CO2 under mild reaction conditions. We are currently investigating further characterizations (in situ/ambient-pressure XPS and X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XANES/EXAFS), together with atomic-resolution HAADF-STEM/EELS) to quantitatively resolve oxidation states, local coordination, and Rh–MoOx interfacial motifs. coredata.dc:description: The selective hydrogenation of CO2 to multi-carbon oxygenates remains a key challenge in heterogeneous catalysis. In this work, a series of M1–M2Ox/TiO2 catalysts (M1 = Ru, Rh, Ir, Pd, Pt; M2 = V, Cr, Mo, W) were systematically screened for low-temperature CO2 hydrogenation to ethanol, and the C2 (ethanol) selectivity was identified as a critical descriptor that serves as a proxy for the intrinsic C–C coupling capacity and preserves the performance ranking at matched CO2 conversion. Among them, the MoOx/Rh/TiO2 catalyst (Rh loading = 1.0 wt%, Mo/Rh molar ratio = 1.0), prepared by the sequential impregnation method, exhibited superior C–C coupling performance, achieving 4.5 % ethanol selectivity and 10.6 % total C2 selectivity at 180 °C and 4 MPa. Mechanistic studies based on contact time variation revealed that CO serves as a key intermediate, with longer residence times favoring C–C bond formation. Structural characterizations (TPD, DRIFTS, TEM, XRD) indicated that MoOx enhances surface basicity and modifies the electronic state of Rh, leading to the coexistence of Rh0 and Rh+ species. This bifunctional surface facilitates both CO2 activation and ethanol formation. These findings highlight the critical role of Rh–MoOx interfacial synergy in enabling selective ethanol production from CO2 under mild conditions, providing insights for the design of efficient catalysts for C2 oxygenate production.
